cluster_relations.rel_desc: Facial expressions are presented as a component or type of body language.
Gestures are presented as components or types of body language.
Posture is presented as a component or type of body language.
Nonverbal cues constitute a substantial portion of overall communication.
Signals sent via body language are part of the communication process.
remarks: Relation semantics chosen to indicate inclusion of signals in communication.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Facial expressions are a component or cue type of body language.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: MentionedAs: subtle cues of body language

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Gestures are a component or cue type of body language.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: MentionedAs: subtle cues of body language

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Posture is a component or cue type of body language.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: MentionedAs: subtle cues of body language

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a more specific subtype, category, or form within the broader category represented by the object.
args.justification: All these relations describe facial expressions, gestures, and posture as types or cue categories of body language (taxonomic inclusion rather than physical part-of). The qualifiers explicitly mark them as subtypes of body language.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a contributing component, modality, or channel within the larger process or system represented by the object.
args.justification: These relations describe nonverbal cues and signals sent through body language as contributing parts/modalities of the overall communication process, which is a compositional, non-taxonomic part-whole relation.
These links organize specific nonverbal cue types (facial expressions, gestures, posture) under the broader category of body language, which is a classic taxonomic hierarchy relation.

Both relations connect specific channels or modalities (nonverbal cues, body-language signals) to the overall communication process, which is best modeled as a family of relations about communication channels/modalities.

Taxonomic subtype relations are conceptually about categorical identity (what kind of thing something is) rather than physical composition or causality, so they fit under a broad IDENTITY / hierarchical grouping.
Nonverbal cues and body-language signals are described as making up a significant portion or component of the larger communication process, which aligns with a compositional part-whole grouping.

executed_decisions.justification: All these relations describe facial expressions, gestures, and posture as types or cue categories of body language (taxonomic inclusion rather than physical part-of). The qualifiers explicitly mark them as subtypes of body language.

Both relations connect specific channels or modalities (nonverbal cues, body-language signals) to the overall communication process, which is best modeled as a family of relations about communication channels/modalities.

Taxonomic subtype relations are conceptually about categorical identity (what kind of thing something is) rather than physical composition or causality, so they fit under a broad IDENTITY / hierarchical grouping.
Nonverbal cues and body-language signals are described as making up a significant portion or component of the larger communication process, which aligns with a compositional part-whole grouping.
